data.text:
He had problems with self-affirmation since childhood. He says that this was one of the reasons why he became interested in cryptography – since he was different, he wanted to be different for everything.

Famous for being the inventor, along with Whitfield Diffie, of a public key cryptography system. In 1976, both published 'New Directions in Cryptography', which introduced a radical change, a new method of key distribution that solved one of the biggest problems in cryptography until then, key distribution.

Hellman won the 2015 Turing Award along with Whitfield Diffie. The Turing Award is widely considered the most prestigious award in the field of computer science. The citation for the award was: “For fundamental contributions to modern cryptography. Diffie and Hellman's groundbreaking 1976 paper, 'New Directions in Cryptography,' introduced the ideas of public-key cryptography and digital signatures, which are the basis for most security protocols on the Internet today.

He studied at the Bronx Institute of Science and earned his degree in Electrical Engineering from New York University in 1966. He completed a master's degree at Stanford University. One of his first jobs was at IBM. He has been a professor at MIT (Massachusetts Institute of Technology) and at Stanford where he was named professor emeritus in 1996.
